title: 103_hr1149
content: The "First-time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 1993" aims to allow individuals to use funds from their retirement plans for first-time home ownership by removing tax and penalty impediments. Owners of individual retirement plans can direct trustees to invest plan funds in the homes of family members who are first-time homebuyers. The "First-time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 1993" allows individuals to use retirement funds for first-time home ownership. The act exempts qualified home equity participation arrangements from prohibited transaction rules under the Internal Revenue Code. The "First-time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 1993" permits retirement funds to acquire an ownership interest in a dwelling unit for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. The arrangement must meet specific ownership interest requirements. The "First-time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 1993" allows retirement funds to invest in a dwelling unit for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. The investment must be repaid upon sale or cessation of use as a principal residence and cannot be used as loan security. The "First-time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 1993" defines terms like eligible participant and first-time homebuyer for retirement funds to invest in a dwelling unit for a principal residence. The "First-time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 1993" defines a qualified family member as a child, parent, or grandparent of the eligible participant. It also includes definitions for acquisition, acquisition cost, and principal residence. The term 'principal residence' in the "First-time Homebuyer Affordability Act of 1993" has the same meaning as in section 1034. The effective date for this amendment is after December 31, 1992. SEC. 4. Loans for first-time homebuyers to acquire principal residences. Loans used to purchase a home for first-time homebuyers from individual retirement plans are exempt from certain tax provisions. A qualified home purchase loan is defined as a loan made by the trustee of an individual retirement plan for the individual's benefit. A qualified home purchase loan from an individual retirement plan must be used for acquiring a dwelling unit to be used as the principal residence for a first-time homebuyer. The loan must be secured by the dwelling unit, repaid in full within 15 years, and any remaining unpaid amount is treated as distributed to the individual after this period. A qualified home purchase loan from an individual retirement plan must be used for acquiring a dwelling unit to be used as the principal residence for a first-time homebuyer. The loan must bear interest at a rate not less than the rate for comparable United States Treasury obligations on the date of the loan. Definitions for terms like 'first-time homebuyer', 'acquisition', and 'principal residence' are provided for clarity. The term 'principal residence' in the context of a qualified home purchase loan refers to the main dwelling where a first-time homebuyer resides. The 'date of acquisition' is defined as the date when a binding contract is entered into or when construction, reconstruction, or improvement of the principal residence begins. The term 'principal residence' for a qualified home purchase loan refers to the main dwelling where a first-time homebuyer resides. The amendments made by this section apply to loans made after December 31, 1992, including any loan that is a qualified home purchase loan as defined in section 408(e)(7)(B).
